author: XnFM
body:
I like AMDs product lineup better, but Intel dominates the system integrator market. Offerings with intel chips frequently outnumber AMD chips by 4:1 and they hold a significant portion of the market for inexpensive consumer machines and office workstations. They're not going away soon. They're starting to produce GPUs again, which may or may not go anywhere, but it's a consideration on a \~5 year horizon.

Personally I don't think  who's going to "win" Intel vs AMD is really all that important in the market space. They're both good companies for different reasons. If intel doesn't turn things around design-wise in a couple years and start producing more competitive products (outside of the bargain and top-end ranges) rather than relying on market dominance, then there's reassessment that needs to happen.

Personally, I think the thing that really needs to be watched in that marketspace is what Nvidia does with ARM. If they can break ARM processors out of the mobile world into the desktop/notebook space then that's a shakeup that could affect the team red/blue balance. We really don't know where that's going yet, and until we do, I still like Intel (it's currently maybe 2% of my portfolio, notwithstanding however much may be held in ETFs).

author: CJT2013
body:
*I assume the few shares you have, won’t be the end of your financial future if AMD Enron’d tomorrow*

If your plan is long term, stick to the plan. We saw these exact same conversations last year in July 2020 when AMD decided to add MiracleGrow to their financials (*Joke*) and it never “Pulled back” “Dipped”. 

This is why advisors always ask, “What is your time horizon?” And “What is your risk tolerance/goal?”

Depending on what got you into the trade will decide.

•What valuation method were/are you using?

•Was it the chip shortage you were capitalizing on?

I’m heavy in AMD and NVDA. Alongside other cash rich tech companies so perhaps I’m biased. Just know there’s people still waiting on the “Pullback” from July 2020. Valuation methods were tough back then and they still are today. That said, I wouldn’t fret over a few shares

author: h4ppyfolk
body:
Lately I've been buying calls 1-3 weeks out on hot stocks that dip  (NVDA was my main moneymaker in June) leading up to or following earnings/split... banking on the following day or two being green enough to get a 25%+ profit. This worked for a little while, but the dips I have been buying lately continue long enough to kill my options. 

I've had three calls in the last week that came alive 1 week before expiry... one I ended up losing 100% on because I waited literally a few minutes too long and kept holding onto hope as it kept decreasing, one for a 40% loss and the other for a 60% profit... both of which continued up all week and my options would've been 4x.  

I rolled my NVDA profits into calls that are one quarter out on stocks that dipped following earnings or a big announcement (NFLX, TSM, ETSY). I'm going to be anxious for the next couple months. 

Anyway, if you got any hot tips, let me know. :)

author: MultiEvents
body:
Please share with me which of my statements is a "broad generalization." This way, I can grow and be a bit more educated. Also, I would love it if you can list several Large Cap Growth companies that pay a 3% or higher dividend. I know of one (BX) that has gone up quite a bit in the last 2+ weeks.

No one buys AAPL for their .60%, MSFT for their .79% dividend, or NVDA for their .80% dividend. Because you might be able to make more money opening up a Savings/checking account or a CD in a bank. People buy those stocks because of their growth. I own all 3 of those stocks. I've had NVDA for about 4 years and it has grown 415%. I've owned MSFT for a little over a 1 year and I am up 55%. I've owned AAPL since August of last year and I am up 18%. 

However, people will buy NLY specifically for its 10.37% dividend, or EPD specifically for its 7.98% dividend, or T specifically for its 7.42% dividend. But, none of those companies are considered "Growth" companies and of course, they do not grow much either.

Growth stocks similar to the ones you mentioned will never pay a high dividend, even though they could afford to. IBM pays a good dividend, but its stock never moves. Three years ago it was at a $152 and today, it is down to $140 (It's not a growth company). CVX pays a good dividend, but it grows at a snail's pace. Three years ago it was at $120 and today it is down to $102 (Not a Growth Company). 

Please, share your knowledge/wisdom.

author: Justjhthings
body:
Can't post a new thread due to insufficient karma. Thus, will be adding this post here.

I have started investing about approximately 1 month ago, and have picked out these stocks and crypto as long term positions. I would be listing out the main reasons on why I have purchased these stocks and crypto, and would like to get some opinions on my current portfolio.  
50% Stocks  
\- Apple (AAPL) 8%  
Apple products are widely used, many loyalists to its product. Still has room for growth and do not see it dying anytime soon. Picked as tech blue chip.  
\- AMD 14%  
Bullish on semiconductors in the long term, picked both AMD and NVDA as forerunners in the industry. Picked for growth potential.  
\- Microsoft (MSFT) 3%  
Similar to AAPL, both companies are huge and have a large customer base, with further room for growth. Picked as second tech blue chip.  
\- Nvidia (NVDA) 5%  
Similar to AMD, hard to pick between both companies, and thus have chosen both. Picked for growth potential.  
\- SEA LTD (SE) 11%  
SEA LTD has 3 subsidiaries, Shopee (e-Commerce), GArena (Gaming) and SEA Money (Digital Payment). A long term pick in which I believe has a chance of being a multi-bagger and that its growth potential has not peaked yet.  
\- Tesla (TSLA) 9%  
Futuristic EV company, a favorite pick of certain investors. Similar reasoning to SE, with a certain amount of risk tied to it.  
20% Cryptocurrency  
\- Ethereum (ETH) 16%  
\- Chainlink (LINK) 4%  
Purchased mainly to gain some exposure to cryptocurrency. Currently viewed as a commodity, in which I believe ETH and LINK has high growth potentials to it.  
30% Cash  
Currently untouched and waiting to be used to buy any potential dips or add positions in other sectors, as I am very exposed to tech-related movements. Will gain about 1% every month from salary, which can then be used to purchase more stocks.   
Currently red on SE, AAPL and MSFT as most of my positions are new and would be looking to average down on these depending on market conditions. Also looking to diversify out of tech with stocks such as Disney (DIS) and Thermo Fisher (TMO). Not adding more funds into crypto, as I feel 20% is already a high ratio.   
Opinions for improvement are welcome.

author: juaggo_
body:
Yes, they work exactly like that. Three things to note with a dividend stock:

1. Good dividend track record. Some companies have raised their dividends every year for decades. Checkout dividend aristocrats.

2. The dividend yield%. If you’re going for a higher yield, make sure the dividend is sustainible.

3. Pay-out ratio. How much does the company give out in dividends? Again looking for the dividend’s sustainability here. Lower pay-out ratios might also mean that the company is still investing their capital and growing. Examples: Apple, Microsoft, Visa and Nvidia.

>It cant be that hard to make a bnpl service if there are so many different ones out there already.   

Product software is incredibly hard. It's not just about building the software, is much, _much_ more than that. I don't think there's _so many_ of these companies either - AFTPY, AFRM, Klarna, and technically PYPL are the major ones I'm aware of. author: bloodyplonker
body:
Your comment is naive and childish at best. You've provided no reasoning on how disruption could happen. ASML has an utter, total, and complete monopoly on those multi-hundred million dollar precision chip cutting machines. Let me ask you this: what kind of company will have the capital and time to be able to newly invent, produce and manufacture multi-hundred million dollar chip and likely fail multiple times in the process? Why would any company go into that when they could do something else and not have to compete with a monopoly?

Paypal, on the other hand is not a monopoly. They have tons of innovative competitors attacking them from all sides, all verticals of their business, including companies like Square and Affirm.

author: juaggo_
body:
So in the beginning, PayPal was trying to get as much as users in the platform as possible. Now that there is 10s of millions, they’ve started to effectively monetize their userbase. You have had the opportunity to buy, hold and sell digital currencies since this April. That is a brilliant addition for Venmo, that is especially favoured among millenials. 

Some small businesses have been using Venmo for payments, so there’s definately more things to do in Venmo than there was a couple of years ago. The growth isn’t stopping, and that’s why Venmo will be a cash cow.

author: Various_Baseball_458
body: PayPal owns Venmo

author: juaggo_
body:
PayPal is a strong fundamental play. They missed their revenue estimates because ebay is finally transitioning out of PayPal’s platform. 

Their userbase is growing still despite already being big with now 403 million users. Venmo is starting to be a cash cow. 

Ecommerce will stay in our lifes. PayPal plays a big part in that and is a huge fintech giant. That’s why you should be in.

author: Summebride
body:
There's two schools of thought right now.  One is that PYPL had run too far, too fast, and is heading back to a more fair value.  That, plus increasing competition in payments forms a thesis that PayPal is going below $250 again.  

There's another school that says the drop was a mistake, a knee jerk response to a surprise dip... but that the dip shouldn't have been a surprise because the EBay breakup was a known known, and just happened slightly earlier than expected.  That school also feels that Venmo is a juggernaut so the existence of competition doesn't bother them.

I've had a small position and my thesis was a bit of each, but I held through earnings with the intent to sell if it popped.  That didn't happen so I had to make a new plan.  I still intend to sell, but now I'm looking to do so into strength when people realize the earnings sell off was a bit much.  Murphy's Law may prevent that, as the story that "there's lots of competition" is one that can be told today, whereas "Venmo is crushing it" is a story that will more likely be told in slower quarterly instalments.

author: AgyleArgyle
body: I agree. Square “spent” 29 billion aka 25% of its market cap to buy afterpay. Paying PS of 40 for its 500 mil revenue generated through 10 billion is BNPL TPV (buy now pay later total payment volume). And by spent, I mean diluted it’s share holders in an all stock deal. To add what PayPal did on a whim 3 quarters ago without dropping a dime. And PayPal’s most recent quarter had 1.5 billion BNPL TPV. For an annual run rate of 6 billion. For free. No dilution. Didn’t buy affirm or klarna.

author: vacchagotta_on_fire
body:
As someone mentioned PayPal = Venmo, but there is still plenty of competition in the app-based payment space (Square, Google, and Apple to name a few).

PayPal may be on top now when it comes to app-based payments like Venmo but that does not mean other Big Tech companies are just going to concede the space. 

Something to be aware of as you invest. I personally do plan to buy the PYPL dip--but not yet. I think it has further to go, especially after the guidance given doesn't predict any revenue growth for the next quarter.
